comments:
I have a new kind of step (for debugging), with its Step Icon and its Step 
pull-down. It has always worked fine in 2.x. It also works fine in 3.x. The 
problem is, on the workspace startup cycle, I get a stack trace in the log. 
I'd like to make it go away. 

Here's the plugin.xml markup to add my new kind of Step:

    <extension point="org.eclipse.ui.actionSets">
       <actionSet
          label="foobar Action Set"
          visible="true"
          id="com.foobar.eclipse.foobarActionSet">

          <menu
             label="Run"
             id="org.eclipse.ui.run"
             path="additions">
             <separator name="foobarGroup"/>
          </menu>

          <action id="com.foobar.eclipse.runmenu.stepFind"
             definitionId="com.foobar.eclipse.runmenu.stepFind"
             label="Step/find @Ctrl+Alt+F7"
             icon="icons/stepfind.gif"
 class="com.foobar.eclipse.debug.gui.StepFindMenuActionDelegate"
             enablesFor="1"
             menubarPath="org.eclipse.ui.run/foobarGroup">

             <selection
                class="com.foobar.eclipse.debug.core.IFoobarStep">
             </selection>
          </action>
       </actionSet>
    </extension>



 The error happens when the workspace tries to run this:


(WorkbenchWindow.java:1861)
                 at org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench.doRestoreState


                 It goes all the way to the top to this:


!ENTRY org.eclipse.jface 4 0 2005-10-18 16:24:33.812
!MESSAGE The command ("com.foobar.eclipse.runmenu.stepFind") is undefined
!STACK 0
java.lang.Exception
                 at
org.eclipse.jface.action.ExternalActionManager$CommandCallback.isActive


  Apart from that, the step button and pull-down menu work fine.

  In 2.x this error did not use to appear in the log. Is this an Eclipse bug 
or a 2.x->3.x incompatibility? Is it documented? I can't find anything so far.

The full stack trace:

The problem seems to be a bad definitionId:

<action 
  id="com.foobar.eclipse.runmenu.stepFind"
  definitionId="com.foobar.eclipse.runmenu.stepFind"


It has to be different from id, and point to a command. Perhaps Eclipse 2.1 
was not catching this problem and 3.1 is, which might explain why it happens 
now.

Yes, in 3.1 code was added to warn plug-in developers that they had written  
code that has no effect.  I wish there was a way of doing this at 
compile-time, but there isn't.  Hence the run-time warnings.
